iterations.failure_reason: Rule hit but no new signatures
improvement_suggestions: Relax the patterns by introducing wildcards (`?`) to account for potential variations in the instruction sequences.  Consider removing the `skip` offsets altogether or significantly reducing their value, as they seem to be causing the execution to jump to unintended locations.  A more targeted approach might involve analyzing the specific purpose of the code being bypassed and creating a rule that focuses on that functionality rather than trying to match a rigid sequence of instructions.

iterations.failure_reason: Rule hit but no new signatures
improvement_suggestions: Remove the `any of them` condition and replace it with an `all of them` condition.  This will require all patterns to match for the rule to trigger, ensuring the skip offset actually takes effect and the rule only fires when the bypass is attempted. Also, broaden the patterns to allow for slight variations in the instruction sequences.

iterations.failure_reason: Rule hit but no new signatures
improvement_suggestions: Instead of fixed skip offsets, utilize more flexible wildcards (`??`) within the patterns to account for variations in the code.  Also, consider removing the `cape_options` entirely and relying on standard YARA matching to identify the relevant code blocks, then incorporating logic within the condition to handle potential variations.  The `cape_options` are meant for more complex, controlled skips that are not applicable here.
